ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

JOHOR CAUSEWAY AND WOODLANDS CHECKPOINT

(Traffic congestion)


    1. Assoc. Prof. Chin Tet Yung asked the Minister for Home Affairs what are the reasons for the traffic jams recently experienced at the Causeway after the opening of the new Woodlands Checkpoint.

    2. Mr Tay Beng Chuan asked the Minister for Home Affairs (a) what are the main contributing factors to the current traffic jams at the Johor Causeway and whether any long-term solutions to the problem are being taken; and (b) whether statistics are available on the number of work permit holders among the total number of commuters travelling across the Causeway daily.

    3. Mr Zulkifli bin Baharudin asked the Minister for Home Affairs what are the reasons for the traffic congestion at the Causeway.

    4. Mr Hawazi Daipi asked the Minister for Home Affairs (a) what caused the recent traffic jams at the Causeway and how this can be avoided in the future; (b) what is the possibility of both the Singapore and Malaysian authorities stepping up cooperation to avoid similar problems at their respective entry and exit points; and (c) whether his Ministry will consider the proposal to use a special pass for lorry drivers and smart card for motorcyclists so that they can clear immigration checks quickly.

    5. Mr Low Thia Khiang asked the Minister for Home Affairs what causes the severe traffic congestion at the Causeway and Woodlands Checkpoint especially during peak hours and what measures have been taken to solve the problem.

    The Minister of State for Home Affairs (Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee) (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Sir, may I take questions 1 to 5 together as they are related?

    Mr Speaker: Yes.

Column: 1877



    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, the morning traffic at the Causeway has always been extremely busy. In the past, because our immigration officers were not able to conduct complete checks, illegal immigrants were able to slip into Singapore, especially during peak hours. In the first half of 1999, more than 70% of the 5,500 illegal immigrants arrested came through the old Woodlands Checkpoint. It is, therefore, necessary to conduct stricter immigration checks at all times. When the new Woodlands Checkpoint opened on 18th July this year, Singapore Immigration and Registration (SIR) started stricter checks.

    Sir, to prepare travellers for the new Woodlands Checkpoint, SIR conducted trial runs over a few days for arriving and departing travellers during the peak-periods. In addition to media publicity, pamphlets in the four official languages were given to all travellers at the old Woodlands Checkpoint.

    There are three incoming lanes into Singapore and three outgoing lanes to Johor on the Causeway. On the first few mornings, there was heavy congestion as vehicles were unable to get into the correct lanes after leaving the Johor checkpoint. In particular, huge numbers of motorcyclists jostled for space among cars, buses and lorries. Lorry traffic was also heavy as usual.

    At the Checkpoint, stricter immigration checks were carried out on travellers, taking about 30 to 45 seconds each. Customs takes about two to three minutes to clear each lorry. There is a red and green lane system for customs clearance for all travellers, including lorries.

    To relieve the congestion, SIR and Traffic Police deployed more officers to direct traffic on the Causeway. One Johor-bound lane was converted into a Singapore-bound lane, making a total of four incoming lanes to Singapore and two outgoing lanes to Johor. More clearance counters were opened.

    Sir, what is the current situation? After the first week, school and factory buses are now generally cleared by 7.00 am, which is better than before; cars are

Column: 1878

moving steadily, also better than before; and the motorcycle queue has eased off earlier, at about 8.00 am instead of 9.00 am at the old checkpoint. The lorry queue remains the same as before.

    The clearance of buses, cars and motorcycles and lorries is now normal. The situation has stabilised.

    On the departure side, there is a marked improvement in the traffic situation. Traffic used to stretch right up to the BKE during the evening peak-hour. It is now confined to near the checkpoint boundaries.

    SIR is looking into ways to further improve the clearance rate at the Checkpoint. There is a smart card clearance system at the bus halls. More regular commuters have applied for these smart cards and will be encouraged to do so. There is also a pilot study to clear motorcyclists through the smart card system.

    There is already a special pass for lorry drivers who make 20 or more trips a month. These Multiple Journey Visit Passes (MJVPs) may be given to more lorry drivers.

    Sir, the congestion during the first few days of operation is unlikely to be repeated. As regards Mr Hawazi's question on both sides stepping up cooperation, there are already links between SIR and Customs, and their Malaysian counterparts.

    Assoc. Prof. Chin Tet Yung (Sembawang): Sir, may I ask the Minister of State to clarify what is meant by "stricter immigration checks"? Is this primarily to control the number of illegal immigrants trying to enter Singapore?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, the Member is correct. As I said, for the first half of this year, out of the 5,500 illegal immigrants who were arrested, 70% or almost 3,800 said that they came through the Woodlands Checkpoint. One reason could be because of the large number of motorcyclists involved. What they did in the past was to flash their travel documents, and only about 12-13% would be checked. So the rest would just flash through. Because of the constraints at the

Column: 1879

old Checkpoint, we could not check everybody. So this is one gap which we feel we have to plug. And so with the new Woodlands Checkpoint, all the motorcyclists and all the other travellers are checked. Their travel documents are given to the customs officers who will look at the photographs and check the particulars against the persons.

    Mr Shriniwas Rai (Nominated Member): Sir, the Tuas Second Link is now under utilised. Would the Government consider working with the Malaysian government in a scheme to popularise its use, so as to ease the congestion at the Woodlands Checkpoint?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, the means of regulating the use of the Causeway and the Second Link are by means of the tolls. And as the Member knows, toll amounts are not just derived at from one side. They are derived from both sides, taking into consideration what each side is paying for the tolls. This is something that cannot just be unilaterally changed by ourselves. In terms of regulating traffic flow, this really comes under the Ministry of Communications and Information Technology (MCIT). It is something that MCIT can consider. Like I said, it is not just a matter of simply raising tolls to regulate traffic. I think what we have to do is that we have to recognise that the main bulk of traffic will still come through the Woodlands Checkpoint. Like I have said, there were, of course, initial teething problems. But arising from the various measures that have been taken, these problems have been largely solved, and the situation has stabilised.

    Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Sir, I have noticed that in the old Woodlands Checkpoint, many of the immigration booths were not opened during peak hours. I do not know whether the Minister has given instructions for all the booths in the new Checkpoint to be opened, especially during the crowded periods.

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, like I have said, one of the measures taken to ameliorate the situation arising in the first few days was the opening of more counters. For example, as a quick check, in

Column: 1880

the old Woodlands Checkpoint, for motorcycles and cars, there were 24 counters. Now, there are 53 counters for motorcycles and cars in the new Woodlands Checkpoint. This is more than double. For buses, at the old Woodlands Checkpoint, there were 10 counters, and now there are 26 counters, including the conversion of some departure counters into arrival counters. Not only has SIR converted one departure lane into an arrival lane so that there is better flow, but for the bus commuters, six of the counters, I understand, have also been so converted to accommodate a faster flow. And lorry counters have been raised from four in the old Woodlands Checkpoint to six.

    Sir, I take Mr Chiam's point that more counters should and indeed have been opened. I think the basic point is that what can be done have been looked at and have been done. But, of course, like I have said, SIR together with the other agencies is still looking at ways to improve the situation, eg, getting more of the commuters, particularly the bus commuters, to go into the immigration access card system. I understand that since the new Woodlands Checkpoint opened, about 4,000 new cards have been issued. So the situation should further improve.

Column: 1880

WOODLANDS CHECKPOINT
(Smuggling of illegal immigrants)


    6. Mr Goh Choon Kang asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether there has been an increase in the number of attempted smuggling of illegal immigrants into Singapore detected at the Woodlands Checkpoint; and what measures have been taken to check this problem.

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, more cases involving the smuggling of illegal immigrants into Singapore have been detected at the Woodlands Checkpoint this year. For the first half of 1999, 10 traffickers and 51 illegal immigrants were arrested, as compared to only one trafficker and two illegal immigrants arrested in the corresponding period last year. In the whole of last year,

Column: 1881

61 foreigners were arrested at the Woodlands Checkpoint for attempting to enter Singapore illegally. Sir, indeed the numbers have gone up.

    Last year, more than 14,700 illegal immigrants were caught in Singapore. SIR estimates that about 70% of them came through the Woodlands Checkpoint. This illustrates that illegal entry into Singapore through the Woodlands Checkpoint is indeed a serious problem. SIR has thus taken a range of measures to check the problem at the Woodlands Checkpoint.

    What are some of these measures? First, like I have mentioned just now, more intensive checks. SIR has, since the later half of 1998, intensified checks at the checkpoint. From July 1998 to June this year, 19 vehicles were seized and forfeited, as compared to only five vehicles in the 12-month period preceding that. With the recent opening of the New Woodlands Checkpoint, SIR has also started conducting more complete checks on travellers and vehicles.

    Second, enhanced intelligence capability. SIR has also enhanced its intelligence capability against syndicates trafficking illegal immigrants. These efforts have paid off, with more syndicate operations being crippled. For the first half of 1999, 10 trafficking cases were detected at the Woodlands Checkpoint as compared to only one case in the first half of 1998.

    Third, more and better trained officers deployed at the Checkpoints. SIR and Police have also deployed more and better-trained officers to intensify checks at both the land checkpoints.

    Lastly, SIR also works with the other Home Team's departments to jointly tackle the illegal immigrant problem. I am sure Members must have read in the papers about the use of SCDF rescue dogs deployed at the Woodlands and Tuas Checkpoints to sniff out illegal immigrants

Column: 1882

concealed in car boots or secret compartments in tourist coaches, lorries, and `Bas Kilang' buses.

    Sir, in addition to rigorous enforcement, we have also spread deterrent messages to potential illegal immigrants and traffickers. Since April 1998, SIR has been issuing pamphlets in four languages to foreigners at the land checkpoints carrying messages on the tough penalties for immigration offences. SIR has also been applying for deterrent sentences to be meted out when traffickers are prosecuted in court.

    Mr Goh Choon Kang (Marine Parade): Sir, can the Minister of State say whether there have been instances where Singapore Immigration has apprehended illegal immigrants trying to leave Singapore by the Causeway? Second, would the Minister of State agree that if the Malaysian authorities also took tough measures to prevent such smuggling from taking place and by crippling the ground operations of these syndicates, it will be a win-win situation for both sides?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, I take it that the Member is referring to illegal immigrants leaving Singapore. SIR also takes a tough stand against illegal immigrants leaving Singapore. Perhaps he has in mind a recent incident at the Causeway where 35 or so illegal immigrants tried to come into Singapore from Malaysia, and some of whom, because they were in a lorry, were killed. I think Members know and have read in the papers that SIR also takes a tough stand against illegal immigrants trying to leave Singapore. I think it stands to reason, because this would add to the deterrence that if you come into Singapore, even if you come in successfully, it would be difficult for you to leave. In any case, these people who successfully leave may return in future. And that is why SIR is vigilant. Indeed, just two days ago, it is in the Straits Times today, a small column, page 3, Members can read about it, a Malaysian registered vehicle was trying to leave Singapore with five Thai illegal immigrants.

Column: 1883



    In 1999, for example, SIR has apprehended 23 such immigration offenders at the Woodlands Checkpoint. In 1998, 138 such immigration offenders tried to leave Singapore illegally, mainly in Malaysian registered cars driven by Malaysians. In the first six months of this year, 53 such offenders were arrested.

    Sir, in answer to the Member's second question, indeed, I agree with him that continued vigilance is important on both sides of the Causeway and I hope that the measures that he has mentioned would be considered by the Malaysian authorities.

    Assoc. Prof. Chin Tet Yung: Given that the illegal immigrants are on the rise and illegal immigrant trafficking seems to be on the rise, is there any intention to review the penalties, especially for the traffickers? I say this in the light of the recent case mentioned by the Minister of State that some illegal immigrants actually died on the way across in that particular incident.

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, the focus now is to plug this flow where in the past they came through the checkpoints. That is the focus of our efforts. In terms of the overall number of illegal immigrants caught, in fact, the number has come down. It has come down by about 30% for the first half of this year compared to the same period last year. But the number is still nevertheless high. I think there is no need at the moment to enhance the penalties. Looking at the situation of each case, for example, the case mentioned by the Member, if the driver is caught, one possibility is to charge him as a trafficker, and he would get up to five years' jail. But again it is up to the Attorney-General's Chambers. If indeed he is caught, the AG may look at the facts and the facts may warrant the AG to consider charging him under a more serious offence, perhaps causing death by a rash act. So there is a range of penalties which can be considered currently.

    Mr Zulkifli Bin Baharudin (Nominated Member): Sir, enforcement against illegal immigrants at the causeway has brought about other problems, especially to companies which require to move goods

Column: 1884

to and from Singapore. How do we ensure that these companies are not affected as more stringent enforcement is conducted?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: If the Member is referring to the lorry queues, the situation, as I have said, has stabilised. Again, initially in the first few days, arising from teething problems, not just the lorries but all the other vehicles were affected. But in the second week of operations that we have monitored, the situation has improved and now the lorry queue is back to normal.

Column: 1884

EMPLOYMENT SITUATION



    7. Mr Harun A. Ghani asked the Minister for Manpower if he will give an update on the employment situation since January 1999 to date, in particular, (a) how many new jobs were created; (b) how many jobs were lost; and (c) whether workers can expect to see better job prospects for the rest of 1999.

    The Minister for Manpower (Dr Lee Boon Yang): Mr Speaker, Sir, the labour market has shown signs of strengthening in the first half of 1999. In tandem with the pick up in economic activities, total employment rose by an estimated 15,400 in the second quarter of 1999. This is the first quarterly increase in employment after declining for four consecutive quarters. For the first half of this year, the total employment gain was 5,800. In other words, jobs created exceeded jobs lost by 5,800. This was a sharp contrast to the net job loss of 26,600 in the second half of 1998 when the impact of the economic downturn on the labour market was most severe.

    Unlike in the previous quarter, nearly all major sectors registered increases in employment in the second quarter of 1999. The employment gains came mainly from the real estate and business services with an estimated net job creation of 8,000, followed by manufacturing at 3,900, financial services at 1,400, hotels and restaurants at 1,200, and transport and communications at 1,000. Employment also rose by 4,300 in the other services sectors covering education, health,

Column: 1885

domestic and other community, social and personal services. In the construction sector, employment continued to contract for the fourth consecutive quarter. However, the net loss of 4,200 construction jobs was significantly less than the 10,500 in the preceding quarter.

    Preliminary findings from a survey of private sector establishments with at least 25 employees showed that about 3,300 workers were retrenched in the second quarter of 1999. This is close to the 3,400 displaced in the previous quarter. With the pick up in the economy, the number of workers retrenched in the first quarter of this year has fallen to 6,700, less than half of the 14,600 laid off in the second half of 1998.

    Recent economic indicators have been very encouraging. Manufacturing output grew by a healthy 10.4% in the first six months of the year compared with the same period last year. Non-oil domestic exports also rebounded with an increase of 10.3% in the second quarter of this year. While the economic situation has certainly improved, the recovery can only be sustained if there is continued strength in the developed economies and a benign environment in the region.

    As the economic recovery gathers momentum, this would have a positive impact on the labour market. We can expect demand for workers to increase while retrenchment is likely to moderate. Nevertheless, there would still be some retrenchments as companies upgrade or restructure to remain competitive. Lower educated workers who lack the necessary skills will remain vulnerable as industries move towards higher value added activities. Workers must not be complacent. They must continue to upgrade themselves to ensure that they are able to take up new jobs that are being created as the economy recovers. That is why my Ministry will continue to support skills upgrading programmes such as the Skills Redevelopment Programme.

    Mr Hawazi Daipi (Sembawang): What is the total number of retrenchment

Column: 1886

expected this year and which sectors would contribute mostly to this retrenchment?

    Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, at this juncture, it is rather difficult to give a final projected figure on the retrenchments likely to be experienced this year. But we know that it would be significantly less than the 29,000-odd workers who were retrenched last year. But it would probably be still a little bit more than the 10,000-11,000 that we experienced prior to the economic downturn in 1998.

    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan (Nominated Member): I would like to ask the Minister three questions. (1) What is the current unemployment rate? (2) What is the net employment creation for the commerce sector? (3) What is the net employment creation for local workers as opposed to foreign workers?

    Dr Lee Boon Yang: Sir, the unemployment rate at the end of March this year was 3.9%. As for the current unemployment rate, the preliminary figures indicated that it is on the decline. It is coming down. We expect the unemployment rate to continue to decline. The figures will only be available when we issue the quarterly economic survey probably later this month.

    As to the details on the employment creation in the commerce sector, I am afraid I do not have the exact figures with me, but I would be prepared to share the information with the Nominated Member.

    As to the net employment creation for local workers as opposed to foreign workers, the demand for foreign workers has actually been fairly stable as a result of the economic downturn. In fact, we saw a dip in demand. In other words, employment creation for foreign workers would have gone down. As a result of the recession, many companies, particularly those in the construction sector, had to release their foreign workers. Therefore, we would expect a decline in the employment creation for foreign workers. But due to the swiftness of the recovery, we are also expecting to see a resurgence

Column: 1887

in the demand for foreign workers and the demand for work permits would rise quite quickly as the manufacturing, commerce and transportation and communication sectors pick up in their business prospects.

    Mr Simon S C Tay (Nominated Member): Sir, may I ask the Minister three points: (1) If one is given the figures year-on-year, as I understand it, how do the job numbers compare to the pre-crisis figures? Have we a net gain? (2) In the down swing, there were concerns about discrimination in job-hiring practices. What measures would the Minister take in the upswing to make sure that the jobs created are hired out fairly? (3) Is there a sense that the type of jobs we are getting are now different from the jobs we had in the pre-crisis days, as certain lower end jobs are gone for good and these people might face, in that sense, structural problems in seeking re-employment?

    Dr Lee Boon Yang: In terms of job creation that we are seeing in the first half of this year compared to the past, in other words, prior to the economic downturn, I have to say that we are still a long way. Between 1992 and 1997, we were creating between 70,000 and 120,000 jobs a year. Last year, we had a net job loss. In the first half of this year, as has been mentioned earlier on, the total employment gain was only 5,800. So we are a long way from what it was before. Perhaps, this is an indicator to say that the economy has not completely recovered to what it used to be pre-1998.

    As to the Member's question on discrimination, whether in the light of the economic downturn, there were any discriminatory practices adopted by employers vis-a-vis local workers versus foreign workers, I have replied to this point on a previous occasion in this Chamber that we have observed during the recession that, on average, when it comes to retrenchment, employers, in fact, retrench their workers without any discriminatory practices. In other words, the retrenchment reflects the profile of the workforce in the company. If the company has 50% local and 50% foreign workers in

Column: 1888

the manufacturing sector, then the retrenchment would take the same proportion. There was no evidence to show that there were clear attempts by employers to retrench Singaporeans and to substitute them with foreign workers.

    On the type of jobs that would be created as the economy recovers, I think this is a very important point. As the economy recovers, we will shift into a new area of competition. Our neighbours will also recover, just as we are recovering, and they will be very much more competitive in some of the more labour-intensive type of businesses, particularly in manufacturing. So, as I have said in my main answer, companies will have to restructure their operations, move on to higher value added activities, bring in new technology and introduce new processes. In fact, as the economy recovers, the jobs that are going to be created will be quite different from the jobs that were available prior to the recession.

    In fact, our workers will have to take note of this and make efforts to upgrade their skills so that they are able to take on the new jobs that are being created. If they do not upgrade their skills, they will find that when the economy recovers, jobs are going a-begging, but the unemployment rate may well stay high, mainly in the form of structural unemployment. This is a serious concern. That is why my Ministry, working together with all the other economic agencies, is putting in efforts to try to address this by providing more opportunities for skills upgrading and retraining to our workers, particularly the older workers and the less educated workers who are most vulnerable to structural unemployment.

    Dr S. Vasoo (Tanjong Pagar): Can I ask the Minister whether the most affected workers are the older workers and what plans are there to enhance their employability?

    Dr Lee Boon Yang: Sir, I agree with the Member that during the economic downturn of last year, the workers who were most affected by unemployment and most vulnerable to retrenchment, were

Column: 1889

indeed the older workers. Many of these older workers missed out on the opportunity for a good education and for skills training when they were younger. Now they are in their mid-40s and they become very vulnerable to retrenchment. In fact, if I recall correctly, they were over-represented among the groups of workers who were retrenched. That is why we have to have special programmes to meet their needs. In the way I responded to the Nominated Member, Mr Simon Tay, we have to put in extra efforts in this area to help the older less-skilled workers to upgrade their skills. The Skills Redevelopment Programme is one such programme focused at meeting the needs of the older workers, helping older, less skilled workers to upgrade, refresh their skills, so that they can take on the new jobs that are being created, in other words, helping them to avoid structural unemployment.

Two questions: (1) Do the latest statistics from the Ministry confirm this? (2) How successful have retrenched Malay workers been looking for new jobs?
